;;Sergio Massa 在获得 36.6% 的选票而 Milei 为 29.9% 的选票后庆祝。这两个人将于 11 月 19 日对决。
;

;拉丁美洲左派领袖庆祝;极右翼民粹主义者哈维尔·米莱 (Javier Milei) 试图在阿根廷总统选举中获得第一轮胜利，但遭到挫败。他的中间派竞争对手塞尔吉奥·马萨。

;

;米莱是一位古怪的经济学家，他称气候变化是“社会主义谎言”，教皇是“左撇子王八蛋”，他曾希望反建制愤怒的爆发能够周日，2700 万阿根廷人在该国数十年来最严重的经济危机中参加了投票，将他推上了总统宝座。

;

;但被广泛认为是选举领跑者的米莱却被庇隆主义财政部长马萨获得了36.6%的选票，而米莱则获得了29.9%的选票。两人将于 11 月 19 日在第二轮对决。

;
;

;;相关：;;极右翼民粹主义者哈维尔·米莱未能赢得阿根廷总统选举第一轮;

;
;

;哥伦比亚左翼总统古斯塔沃·佩特罗 (Gustavo Petro) 领导庆祝了米莱的意外挫折，这对全球极右翼成员造成了沉重打击，他们希望米莱的胜利能让他们做出强有力的决定展示力量。

;

;“阿根廷已经击败了野蛮行为，”佩特罗在推特上写道。 “这是充满希望的时刻。”

;

;巴西左翼总统路易斯·伊纳西奥·卢拉·达席尔瓦也纪念了大多数民意调查未能预见到的结果。 “太棒了，我的朋友，”;卢拉据阿根廷报纸《Clarín》报道，据报道;在给马萨的私人信息中写道。

;

;卢拉的首席外交政策顾问塞尔索·阿莫林 (Celso Amorim) ;称为; 结果一尽管他警告说“斗争还没有结束”，但“救济和重燃希望”。卢拉的通讯部长保罗·皮门塔 (Paulo Pimenta) 在推特上写道：“民主万岁！”米莱周日晚上在布宜诺斯艾利斯向支持者发表讲话时，对他未能获胜做出了积极的解释，称他参加了决选“真正的历史性成就”。

;

;米雷是一位电视名人，2021 年才进入政坛，他呼吁马萨庇隆主义联盟的所有反对者团结起来，共同打击他所指责的“犯罪组织”。数字通货膨胀并使阿根廷 4600 万公民中的 40% 陷入贫困。

;
;

;;相关：;;“他的行为就像金刚狼”：谁是阿根廷总统领跑者哈维尔·米莱？;

;
;

;“如果我们共同努力，我们就能获胜。如果我们共同努力，我们就能恢复我们的国家。”米莱坚称，她希望能吸引支持第三名候选人、保守派前安全部长帕特里夏·布尔里奇的 5600 万选民中的一些人。预计将有 250 万张选票投向第四名和第五名的中左翼和左翼候选人胡安·斯基亚雷蒂 (Juan Schiaretti) 和米里亚姆·布雷格曼 (Myriam Bregman)。

;

;因为她在周日晚上接受了失败，布尔里奇强烈暗示她会支持米莱，发誓永远不会成为她指责的庇隆主义民粹主义者的“同谋”;阿根廷;并产生了“历史上最糟糕的政府”。

;

;拉丁美洲极右翼的杰出成员反对米莱获得第二名的描述作为翻牌。巴西前总统雅伊尔·博尔索纳罗 (Jair Bolsonaro) 的儿子国会议员爱德华多·博尔索纳罗 (Eduardo Bolsonaro) 表示，“米莱肯定会成为第二轮的热门人选。”爱德华多·博尔索纳罗飞抵布宜诺斯艾利斯，希望庆祝极右翼的胜利，就像他父亲 2018 年巴西大选那样。

; ;

;博索纳罗分享了;一段病毒视频;，一名阿根廷人打扮成电锯投票——这是米莱竞选活动的象征削减开支并切断阿根廷的政治体制——以此证明他的运动是不可阻挡的“现象”。

;

;但是，在这位自称为“无政府资本主义者”的豪华酒店外面，米莱斯塔斯的挫败感显而易见。成为他的竞选总部。垂头丧气的米雷支持者聚集在大楼外，期待着第一轮的胜利，但最终没有实现，他们在没有证据的情况下声称投票被操纵了。

;

;“这伤害了我的灵魂。我预计他会在第一轮获胜。我很惊讶，”22 岁的米莱支持者伊万·冈萨雷斯 (Ivan González) 承认道，他戴着唐纳德·特朗普 (Donald Trump) 帽子，举着黄色加兹登旗帜 - 美国极右翼和米莱运动使用的美国革命时代旗帜。

;

;冈萨雷斯将周日的挫折归咎于马萨的“FEA 贩卖”活动，但坚称他没有放弃第二轮获胜的希望。

;
;

;;相关：;;阿根廷极右翼领跑者重新揭开独裁统治的伤口;

;
;

;《美洲季刊》主编布莱恩·温特表示，现在很难说这两位候选人中哪一位最有可能成为总统。温特将米雷未能脱颖而出的原因归咎于选民对他的性格、执政能力和激进思想抱有太多怀疑，其中包括放宽枪支法、质疑阿根廷1976-83年独裁统治期间被杀的人数等。温特怀疑米莱的竞选活动过于强调堕胎和枪支文化等文化战争问题，并且与特朗普等右翼人物走得太近，从而吓跑了一些选民。和博尔索纳罗。

;

;“我认为那些将;模因;与米莱放在一起的人、博尔索纳罗和特朗普并没有给米莱任何好处。这种保守主义风格会让你在阿根廷获得 30% 的支持率，但不会让你达到 50%，”Winter 说。 “阿根廷不是巴西，阿根廷也不是德克萨斯州……阿根廷不是一个拥枪议程能够占上风的国家。”

;

;尽管如此，温特相信，如果米莱能够成功，他仍然有通往胜利的道路。可以获得前保守派总统毛里西奥·马克里等有影响力的政治人物的支持，并向选民展示“更加温和”的面孔。 “（阿根廷）是一个人们迫切渴望变革的国家 - 所以不要把米莱排除在外。”

;

;资深拉丁美洲观察家迈克尔·里德 (Michael Reid) 在 Twitter 上写道：“要么可以获胜，但马萨现在比米莱更容易登上总统宝座......米莱已经失去了最宝贵的政治品质和动力，并且可能很难恢复它。”

;;'她为什么死？这是个大问题……Vergie Tamfungan。
;

;阿联酋政府已运回一名上个月死亡的菲律宾家庭佣工的尸体，并对;《卫报》关于将她带入该国的招聘人员的报告;。;

;当 39 岁的 Vergie Tamfungan 于 9 月 25 日去世时，她被关押在沙迦酋长国的招聘人员住处，尚未被安置在一个家庭中工作。她的家人表示，在该机构承诺给她丰厚的薪水和奖金后，她当月就去了阿联酋。

;

;“阿联酋人力资源和酋长国部对夫人不幸去世深感悲痛。维尔吉·塔姆丰甘。在这个极其困难的时刻，我们向她的家人致以慰问。”阿联酋政府在一份声明中表示。

;

;“该部已启动彻底调查，以调查塔姆芬甘女士在阿联酋期间非法就业的问题。持旅游签证前往阿联酋。调查将确保违法者，无论是个人还是公司，都将被追究责任。”声明补充道。 “阿联酋非常重视海外劳动力做出的贡献，并致力于全面保护和增强工人的权利和福利。”

;

;Tamfungan，来自塞布湖的四个孩子的母亲菲律宾人已在沙特阿拉伯合法从事家庭佣工四年。八月，阿联酋的一名招聘人员向她提供了工作，据信该招聘人员没有经营许可证。这被菲律宾海外工人群体称为“跨国”——当你离开一个国家的雇主去另一个国家工作而没有向菲律宾政府登记你的就业情况时，实际上就变成了无证身份。

;

;菲律宾政府移民工人部门迪拜办事处今年对跨国就业发出警告，并表示这是非法的，相当于“人口贩卖”。

;

;Tamfungan 的招聘人员是一名来自菲律宾的女性，住在菲律宾阿联酋拒绝向 Tamfungan 的家人透露公司名称和其他详细信息。由于缺乏信息，他们很难获得菲律宾当局的援助。

;
;

;;相关：;;被奖金和大笔资金引诱到阿联酋，Vergie Tamfungan 发生了什么？;

;
;

;塔姆芬甘的死因尚不清楚。阿联酋当局称其为“心脏骤停”。 Tamfungan 的家人说，她之前很健康，没有任何潜在疾病。

;

;“她为什么会死？这是一个大问题，”Tamfungan 17 岁的女儿 Gellian 说。

;

;他们告诉《卫报》，家人希望在菲律宾进行尸检，但无力支付费用。它们的价格高达 10,000 菲律宾比索（145 英镑）。

;

;高达 ;估计每年有 10,000 名来自亚洲的移民工人在沙特阿拉伯、阿联酋等海湾国家死亡; 、巴林、卡塔尔、阿曼和科威特。据人权组织称，超过一半的死亡原因不明，经常使用“自然原因”和“心脏骤停”等术语。

; Tue, 24 Oct 2023 00:22:02 +0800 Rapid ice melt in west Antarctica now inevitable, research showshttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/23/rapid-ice-melt-in-west-antarctica-now-inevitable-research-shows
;;2023-10-23T15:00:03Z;
;
;;南极洲西部马蹄岛上的冰山正在融化。
;

;南极洲西部冰层加速融化是不可避免的研究表明，在本世纪剩余时间内，无论碳排放量减少多少。科学家表示，海平面上升的影响是“可怕的”，这意味着一些沿海城市可能不得不被废弃。

;

;如果完全消失，南极洲西部的冰盖将使海洋上升 5 米。之前的研究表明，它注定会; 在几个世纪的过程中崩溃;，但新的研究表明，即使在未来几十年内大幅削减排放也不会减缓融化。

;

;分析显示了漂浮冰架的融化速度即使世界实现了《巴黎协定》中最雄心勃勃的目标，即将全球升温控制在比工业化前水平高出 1.5 摄氏度以下，阿蒙森海的海水温度将比上个世纪快三倍。

;

;漂浮的冰架意味着陆地上的冰川冰盖可以自由地更快地滑入海洋。从纽约到孟买再到上海，数百万人生活在容易受到海平面上升影响的沿海城市，并且超过;全球三分之一的人口生活在; 62 英里范围内（ 100公里）的海岸。

;

;气候危机正在通过冰盖和冰川的融化以及海水的热膨胀推动海平面上升。科学家们表示，未来海平面上升的最大不确定性是南极洲将会发生什么，这使得适应海平面上升的计划变得非常困难。研究人员表示，迫切需要将冰融化的新发现转化为海平面上升的具体估计。

;

;“我们的研究并不是什么好消息——我们可能已经在 21 日失去了对南极西部冰架融化的控制。领导这项工作的英国南极调查局凯特琳·诺顿博士说。 “这是气候变化的影响之一，我们可能不得不适应，这很可能意味着一些沿海社区要么必须建立[防御]，要么被放弃。”Naughten 说。她的研究表明，情况比之前想象的更加危险。 “但我们不应该放弃（气候行动），因为即使这种特殊影响是不可避免的，它也只是气候变化的影响之一，”她补充道。 “我们的行动可能会在 22 世纪及以后对[南极冰融化]产生影响，但这个时间尺度可能我们今天都无法看到。”

;

;Taimoor Sohail 博士，澳大利亚新南威尔士大学（未参与该研究）表示：“南极西部冰盖的崩塌是一个令人担忧的气候临界点。这项评估表明，冰架加速融化已被锁定。这对海平面上升的影响是可怕的。”

;

;英国国家海洋学中心的蒂亚戈·塞加比纳齐·多托 (Tiago Segabinazzi Dotto) 博士表示：“很可能我们已经过了一个临界点，以避免南极西部冰盖的不稳定。然而，这种崩溃的速度仍然不确定——对于某些特定的冰架来说，它可能会在几十年或几个世纪内发生。

;

;“这项工作的结论是基于单一模型，需要谨慎对待。 ”但他表示，研究结果的一些细节与之前的研究一致：“[这]让人们相信政策制定者需要考虑这项研究。”

;

;这项研究，;发表在《自然气候变化》杂志上;，使用阿蒙森海的高分辨率计算机模型对全球变暖进行了最全面的评估迄今为止的地区。结果表明，在所有可能减少化石燃料燃烧速度的情况下，21 世纪融化速度的加快都是不可避免的。

;

;一个重要因素是南极洲西部的自然气候变率非常显着，这些沼泽融化的差异，快速、中等和缓慢减排情景之间冰融化的微小差异。

;

;Naughten 说：“世界上已经存在难民危机，[海平面上升]只会让情况变得更糟。根据海平面上升的程度，我们将如何应对数百万人甚至可能超过十亿人的流离失所？”

;

;英国南安普顿大学的 Alberto Naveira Garabato 教授说：“这是一项发人深省的研究。然而，它也应该起到警钟的作用。如果我们从过去的不作为中吸取教训并立即开始减少温室气体排放，我们仍然可以拯救[东部]南极冰盖，该冰盖的海平面上升了约10倍米。”

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 23:22:01 +0800 Salman Rushdie: allow writers to create characters outside of their own experiencehttps://www.theguardian.com/books/2023/oct/23/salman-rushdie-allow-writers-to-create-characters-outside-of-their-own-experience
;;2023-10-23T13:49:41Z;
;
;;作者 Salman Rushdie
;

;;萨尔曼·拉什迪;说过，如果只允许作者写出反映他们自己和他们自己经历的人物，“小说的艺术就不复存在了” ”。

;

;“如果我们生活在一个只有女性才能写女性、只有印度人才能写印度人、只有异性恋者才能写异性恋者的世界……那就是死亡据《泰晤士报》报道，小说家说道：“艺术。”

;
;

;;相关：;;萨尔曼·拉什迪宣布出版回忆录《Knife》，讲述 2022 年被刺伤的事情;

;
;

;在;法兰克福书展新闻发布会上讲话; 周五，这位出生于印度的英裔美国作家还表示，他在 ;哈马斯于 10 月 7 日对以色列发动袭击;。他补充说，他对以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡“可能会做出什么回报”感到“充满不祥的预感”，并希望“尽早停止敌对行动”。

;

;此次活动标志着拉什迪罕见的公开露面，他于 2022 年 8 月在纽约州的舞台上遭遇持刀袭击，幸存下来。33 年前，伊朗针对《;《撒旦诗篇》;，被认为是亵渎神明的。

;

;本月早些时候，有人宣布拉什迪关于这次袭击的回忆录，题为《刀》 ，将于 2024 年 4 月出版。在新闻发布会上被问及即将出版的书时，拉什迪表示，似乎“不可能再写任何东西了”。他还表示，这是“艰难的一年”，他“很高兴仍然留在这里”。

;

;拉什迪还在周日获得了德国图书贸易享有盛誉的和平奖，并利用这个机会致电据美联社报道，这是为了无条件捍卫言论自由。今年早些时候，25,000 欧元（21,786 英镑）奖金的德国评审团表示，他们表彰拉什迪“因为他的决心、他对生活的积极态度以及他以叙述的乐趣丰富了世界”。;德国新闻媒体 DW 采访;。 “作家能做的——以及他们正在做的——就是试图表达许多人现在所感受到的难以置信的痛苦，并让全世界关注这一点。”

;

;至少有 1,400 人遇难。本月早些时候对以色列的袭击，巴勒斯坦卫生部表示，自 10 月 7 日以来，至少有 5,087 名巴勒斯坦人在以色列对加沙的袭击中丧生。世界上最大的法兰克福书展在取消原计划的 ;庆祝巴勒斯坦作家阿达尼亚·希比利的颁奖典礼;。

;

;在周五的新闻发布会上，拉什迪还谴责了;最近起诉布克奖获奖小说家的举措Arundhati Roy;，表彰她在 2010 年发表的有关克什米尔的演讲。据法新社报道，拉什迪说：“她是印度最伟大的作家之一，也是一个非常正直和热情的人。” “认为她应该因为表达这些价值观而被带上法庭的想法是可耻的。”

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 22:22:02 +0800 World’s oldest known dog dies aged 31 after being saved from shallow grave as puphttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/23/worlds-oldest-known-dog-dies-aged-31-after-being-saved-from-shallow-grave-as-pup
;;2023-10-23T13:31:17Z;
;
;;世界上最古老的狗波比的照片。
;

;当一只棕白色的狗时1992 年 5 月 11 日，一只名叫波比的小狗喵喵地来到这个世界，南斯拉夫正在分裂，洛杉矶仍在因骚乱而闷烧，《马斯特里赫特条约》的墨迹已干，莎朗·斯通在《本能》中引诱迈克尔·道格拉斯，距离《快速行动》还有五个月的时间发布自动为人民。

;

;这只已故的狗以 31 岁零 165 天的惊人年龄去世，与其说它打破了世界上最长寿狗的记录，不如说它猛烈地撼动了它。一边对一边，把它撕成碎片，埋掉，然后用一条胜利的腿（如果是年老的话）翘起它。

;

;10 月 21 日，Rafeiro do Alentejo 品种的 Bobi 在葡萄牙村庄摘下了他的凡人项圈。孔奎罗斯，他与莱昂内尔·科斯塔 (Leonel Costa) 及其家人一起度过了一生。

;

;最早的致敬之一来自吉尼斯世界纪录，该记录称这是 ;“得知世界上最年长的狗博比去世的消息，我们深感悲痛”。 Bobi was awarded the title of ;world's oldest living dog in February this year;, effortlessly snatching the crown from the paws of ;Spike the chihuahua, a young pretender from Ohio; who died as a mere pup in comparison at the age of 23 years and seven days.

;

;Until Bobi's death on Saturday, the planet's most ancient recorded canine was ;Bluey, an Australian cattle-dog; who died in 1939 at the age of 29 years 5 months.

;

;Bobi was registered in 1992 with the veterinary service of the central Portuguese municipality of Leiria, which confirmed his birthdate. His age had also been verified by a pet database managed by Portugal's National Union of Veterinarians.

;

;Bobi's death was announced by Dr Karen Becker, a vet who met Bobi several times.

;

;“Last night, this sweet boy earned his wings,” ;she posted on Facebook;, alongside two pictures of a cheerful-looking Bobi.

;

;“Despite outliving every dog in history, his 11,478 days on Earth would never be enough, for those who loved him.”

;
;

;;Related: ;;The pet I'll never forget: Glenn was a funny, barky dream of a dog. Then one day he just wasn't there;

;
;

;Bobi's exceptional longevity – his livestock-guarding breed typically lives for 12 to 14 years – is all the more remarkable given the less than propitious circumstances of his earliest days.

;

;At birth, Bobi and his three male siblings were deemed surplus to requirements and were destined for a shallow grave before fate – with an eight-year-old Leonel Costa and his brothers – intervened.

;

;“Unfortunately, at that time it was considered normal by older people … to bury the animals in a hole so that they would not survive,” said Leonel Costa.

;

;When Costa's parents went to dispose of the puppies, Bobi had the nous, or good fortune, to be hidden in a stack of wood in an outbuilding. Spared the shovel and the grave, he was then adopted by Leonel and his brothers and soon became part of the family.

;

;Costa has attributed Bobi's long life to the “calm, peaceful” environment in which he lived, to the fact that he always had the run of the land, and to the diet of the family's dogs.

;

;“What we ate, they ate too,” he said, adding that he did, however, soak Bobi's food in water to remove seasonings.

;

;Nature and nurture both appear to have played their part: Bobi's mother, Gira, lived to 18, while another of Costa's dogs, Chicote, made it to 22.

;

;“We see situations like this as a normal result of the life that they have,” Costa said when his elderly companion scooped the title earlier this year. “But Bobi is one of a kind.”

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 21:52:01 +0800 Italian government to change rules after doctors fined for Covid overtimehttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/23/italy-overtime-rules-fines-bari-doctors-hospital-covid-pandemic
;;2023-10-23T13:11:54Z;
;
;;A healthcare worker wearing a mask, visor, gloves and a full-body protective suit sprays disinfectant on a colleague wearing the same outfit
;

;The Italian health minister has promised to change draconian employment regulations affecting medical employees after three doctors received fines totalling €37,000 (£32,000) for working too much during the coronavirus pandemic.

;

;Orazio Schillaci's comments came after Vito Procacci, the chief of the emergency unit at the general hospital in Bari, Puglia, said he had been fined €27,000 by the local labour inspectorate for breaching overtime rules and not taking obligatory breaks. Two of his colleagues at the hospital were also fined €10,000 between them.

;

;Procacci wrote a letter to the Italian president, Sergio Mattarella, who then intervened to have the penalties suspended.

;

;Their predicament has prompted a debate on the pressures engulfing the Italian healthcare system amid an exodus of professionals.

;

;“Yesterday we were heroes; today we are transgressors,” Procacci wrote on Facebook, adding that the fines were “an insult to Italian healthcare workers but also to citizens who experienced suffering and grief because of the pandemic”.

;

;Schillaci said the rules must be changed in order to avoid a repeat of staff being fined for working overtime.

;

;“We are ready to offer all our support to find the most suitable solutions so that these regulations are quickly corrected, the sanctions are cancelled and an end is put to this paradoxical affair,” he said. “The state cannot sanction its own doctors and health workers after having asked for, and obtained, an extraordinary commitment from them at a time of exceptional emergency.”

;

;The labour minister, Marina Calderone, said an inspection had been carried out at the Bari hospital after a trade union made complaints over excessive working hours of medical staff during 2021. “The inspectorate will proceed, over the next few days, with further investigations to evaluate the cancellation of the sanctions imposed,” she added.

;

;In the letter to Mattarella, Procacci said his hospital had saved 8,600 lives during the pandemic, and that he was “dismayed and disappointed” by the way the state had treated him.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Reporting on Covid-19 in Italy: 'Life as we've known it has stopped';

;
;

;Italy was the ;first country; in Europe to be hit by a widespread outbreak of Covid-19, forcing healthcare staff to work long hours in gruelling conditions. To date, 381 health workers have died of the virus, according to the most recent figures from Fnomceo, the national federation of surgeons and dentists.

;

;The medics' penalties turned the spotlight on a public system that has lost more than 11,000 medics since 2021, with low pay and stress prompting professionals to either retire early, switch to the private sector or seek better opportunities abroad.

;

;A report by Fnomceo in early September found that of the health workers going abroad, the majority had moved to countries in the Gulf, with Saudi Arabia being the most “in demand” destination, followed by the UAE, Qatar and Bahrain.

;

;Meanwhile, regional health authorities are plugging shortages by recruiting from abroad. In August, a further 120 medics from Cuba arrived in the southern region of Calabria as part of an initiative that began last year. Authorities in Venice launched an appeal for GPs in July, offering incentives such as subsidised rates on surgery premises, help with providing accommodation and free parking on the edges of the lagoon city.

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 21:52:01 +0800 UK officials use AI to decide on issues from benefits to marriage licenceshttps://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/oct/23/uk-officials-use-ai-to-decide-on-issues-from-benefits-to-marriage-licences
;;2023-10-23T13:00:00Z;
;
;;A graphic showing Home office logo transforming into pixelated data.
;

;Government officials are using artificial intelligence (AI) and complex algorithms to help decide everything from who gets benefits to who should have their marriage licence approved, according to a Guardian investigation.

;

;The findings shed light on the haphazard and often uncontrolled way that cutting-edge technology is being used across Whitehall.

;

;Civil servants in at least eight Whitehall departments and a handful of police forces are using AI in a range of areas, but especially when it comes to helping them make decisions over welfare, immigration and criminal justice, the investigation shows.

;
;

;;Related: ;;AI should be licensed like medicines or nuclear power, Labour suggests;

;
;

;The Guardian has uncovered evidence that some of the tools being used have the potential to produce discriminatory results, such as:

;

;;•; An algorithm used by the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) which an MP believes mistakenly led to dozens of people having their benefits removed.

;

;;•; A facial recognition tool used by the Metropolitan police has been found to make more mistakes recognising black faces than white ones under certain settings.

;

;;•; An algorithm used by the Home Office to flag up sham marriages which has been disproportionately selecting people of certain nationalities.

;

;Artificial intelligence is typically “trained” on a large dataset and then analyses that data in ways which even those who have developed the tools sometimes do not fully understand.

;

;If the data shows evidence of discrimination, experts warn, the AI tool is likely to lead to discriminatory outcomes as well.

;

;Rishi Sunak ;recently spoke; in glowing terms about how AI could transform public services, “from saving teachers hundreds of hours of time spent lesson planning to helping NHS patients get quicker diagnoses and more accurate tests”.

;

;But its use in the public sector has previously proved controversial, such as ;in the Netherlands;, where tax authorities used it to spot potential child care benefits fraud, but were fined €3.7m after repeatedly getting decisions wrong and plunging tens of thousands of families into poverty.

;

;Experts worry about a repeat of that scandal in the UK, warning that British officials are using poorly-understood algorithms to make life-changing decisions without the people affected by those decisions even knowing about it. Many are concerned about the abolition ;earlier this year; of an independent government advisory board which held public sector bodies accountable for how they used AI.

;

;Shameem Ahmad, the chief executive of the Public Law Project, said: “AI comes with tremendous potential for social good. For instance, we can make things more efficient. But we cannot ignore the serious risks.

;

;“Without urgent action, we could sleep-walk into a situation where opaque automated systems are regularly, possibly unlawfully, used in life-altering ways, and where people will not be able to seek redress when those processes go wrong.”

;

;Marion Oswald, a professor in law at Northumbria University and a former member of the government's advisory board on data ethics, said: “There is a lack of consistency and transparency in the way that AI is being used in the public sector. A lot of these tools will affect many people in their everyday lives, for example those who claim benefits, but people don't understand why they are being used and don't have the opportunity to challenge them.”

;

;Sunak will gather heads of state next week at Bletchley Park for ;an international summit on AI safety;. The summit, which Downing Street hopes will set the terms for AI development around the world for years to come, will focus specifically on the potential threat posed to all of humanity by advanced algorithmic models.

;

;For years, however, civil servants have been relying on less sophisticated algorithmic tools to help make a range of decisions about people's daily lives.

;

;In some cases, the tools are simple and transparent, such as electronic passport gates or number plate recognition cameras, both of which use visual recognition software powered by AI.

;

;In other cases, however, the software is more powerful and less obvious to those who are affected by it.

;

;The Cabinet Office recently launched an ;“algorithmic transparency reporting standard”;, which encourages departments and police authorities to voluntarily disclose where they use AI to help make decisions which could have a material impact on the general public.

;

;Six organisations have listed projects under the new transparency standard.

;

;The Guardian examined those projects, as well as ;a separate database; compiled by the Public Law Project. The Guardian then issued freedom of information requests to every government department and police authority in the UK to build a fuller picture of where AI is currently making decisions which affect people's lives.

;

;The results show that at least eight Whitehall departments use AI in one way or another, some far more heavily than others.

; ;

;The NHS has used AI in a number of contexts, including during the Covid pandemic, when officials used it to help identify at-risk patients who should be advised to shield.

;

;The Home Office said it used AI for e-gates to read passports at airports, to help with the submission of passport applications and in the department's “sham marriage triage tool”, which flags potential fake marriages for further investigation.

;

;An internal Home Office evaluation seen by the Guardian shows the tool disproportionately flags up people from Albania, Greece, Romania and Bulgaria.

;

;The DWP, meanwhile, has an “integrated risk and intelligence service”, which uses an algorithm to help detect fraud and error among benefits claimants. The Labour MP Kate Osamor believes the use of this algorithm may have contributed to dozens of Bulgarians suddenly ;having their benefits suspended; in recent years after they were falsely flagged as making potentially fraudulent claims.

;

;The DWP insists the algorithm does not take nationality into account. A spokesperson added: “We are cracking down on those who try to exploit the system and shamelessly steal from those most in need as we continue our drive to save the taxpayer £1.3bn next year.”

;

;Neither the DWP nor the Home Office would give details of how the automated processes work, but both have said the processes they use are fair because the final decisions are made by people. Many experts worry, however, that biased algorithms will lead to biased final decisions, because officials can only review the cases flagged to them and often have limited time to do so.

; Mon, 23 Oct 2023 21:22:01 +0800 Moon may be ‘40m years older’ than previously thought, researchers sayhttps://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/oct/23/moon-may-be-40m-years-older-than-previously-thought-researchers-say
;;2023-10-23T12:25:18Z;
;
;;Scientist-astronaut Harrison H. Schmitt on the moon during the Apollo 17 mission in 1972.
;

;It has shone down upon the dinosaurs, inspired the greatest poets, and been explored by intrepid astronauts. But despite its enduring presence, quite when the moon came into being has remained a matter of debate. Now researchers say they have the answer, revealing the Earth's satellite is 40m years older than previously thought.

;

;Scientists made their discovery by studying crystals within lunar dust that was brought back in 1972 as part of the Apollo 17 mission – the last time astronauts set foot on the moon.

;

;“It's amazing being able to have proof that the rock you're holding is the oldest bit of the moon we've found so far. It's an anchor point for so many questions about the Earth. When you know how old something is, you can better understand what has happened to it in its history,” said Dr Jennika Greer of the University of Glasgow, the study's lead author.

;

;Around 100m years after the formation of the solar system, when the planets had already formed, it is thought a Mars-size body struck Earth, ejecting a large mass of material that eventually became the moon. The energy involved in the impact meant its surface was initially molten, but as the lunar magma ocean cooled the material solidified.

;

;Crucially, it is thought the crystals scrutinised in the study formed during this cooling process, meaning their composition offers researchers the chance to probe their age, and hence the age of the moon itself.

;

;However, pinning down such timings has been tricky.; ;Some; work on lunar materials together with modelling;; ;has suggested the moon is about 4.42bn years old, but recent research into the crystals has; suggested it could be even older;.

;

;Now researchers say new analytical techniques appear to confirm that the crystals formed further back in time.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'Streets on the moon': lunar dust could be 'melted' to make solid roads;

;
;

;The approach, known as atom probe tomography, involves using a laser to evaporate atoms from crystals that have been sharpened to a very fine “nano tip”. The mass of these atoms can then be detected and the proportion of different types of uranium and lead atoms – known as isotopes – can be measured. Because uranium turns into lead over time through radioactive decay, this proportion can shed light on how old the crystals are.

;

;The upshot, ;the team write in the journal Geochemical Perspectives Letters,; is that the crystals, and hence our satellite, appear to be at least 4.46 bn years old.

;

;“This age pushes back the age of the first preserved lunar crust by ∼40 [million years] and provides a minimum formation age for the moon within 110 [million years] after the formation of the solar system,” the team write.

;

;They suggest samples of such crystals which give rise to the conclusion of a younger age could be down to the loss of lead in the material after crystallisation, skewing the resulting dating.

;

;Dr Romain Tartèse of the University of Manchester, who was not involved in the research, welcomed the study.

;

;“This indicates that the moon is at least 4.46 [billion years old], which contradicts some of the recent proposals for a young moon formation,” he said.

;

;The revelation, he added, suggests the giant impact with Earth from which the moon formed likely occurred a few tens of million years before that point.

;

;However, Tartèse noted the study assumes that the findings from the Apollo samples applies to the whole moon, which may not be the case.

;

;“This underlines the importance of returning further samples from different regions of the moon through future missions,” he said.

;

;“This study also exemplifies the great benefit of sample return missions and proper curation,” Tartèse added. “More than 50 years after these samples were returned we are still making key discovery about the moon and the inner solar system as technology continues developing.”

;Hikvision, the Chinese surveillance firm identified by the UK government as a security threat, has “recommitted” to Britain after receiving clarification that a ban on its cameras being positioned at sensitive sites does not extend to public authorities or police stations.

;

;In a message to clients, the Chinese state-owned company, whose equipment is prohibited in the US on national security grounds, said the new guidance would allow it to “move forward with our mission”.

;

;The permissive approach to Hikvision, whose cameras have reportedly been used in Uyghur “re-education camps” in the autonomous territory of Xinjiang in north-west China, has been adopted despite ministers conceding last November that the camera systems and their connectivity posed a threat to the UK's security.

;

;In a statement to the Commons last year, Oliver Dowden, now the deputy prime minister, said the government was taking “action now to prevent any security risks materialising” by ceasing deployment at “sensitive sites”.

;

;In a letter to Hikvision sent this August, the government's chief security adviser, Vincent Devine, informed the Chinese company, that while the definition of “sensitive sites” was “not public”, it applied to areas “on the central government estate where security consideration are always paramount – for example, defence and intelligence facilities”.

;

;Devine went on to reassure the Chinese company: “The policy represents instruction and advice to central government departments. It does not apply to private individuals or businesses or other public authorities (outside the central government estate) and was not intended to be relied upon by such persons in relation to their own use of visual surveillance equipment. The policy did not respond to any specific request for a 'ban' on the use of Hikvision products.”

;

;The former cabinet minister Iain Duncan Smith, who has long raised concerns about the role of the Chinese state in the UK, said the guidance provided to Hikvision was not in line with what he had been told would be government policy.

;
